text: after the uprising our new robot
overlords will have to decide what to
teach us during our mandatory
re-education and so I trained a neural
network to simulate what those classes
might be like some examples were how to
sex a tablet absolute beginners
gluten-free retouching in Photoshop
fonts how to speak love and learn basic
pizzle their fundamentals of hands 824
ways to use or my personal favorite
create a wedding butter scrub fast easy
and seamless deaths and before I get too
far I want to first say that this video
is sponsored by skill share and not just
sponsored as you might have guessed
skill share actually allowed me to use
their database of at the time I started
this video twenty eight thousand four
hundred and nine classes so it was a
great opportunity to have fun with this
huge data set and try out some cool new
things you may have seen some of my past
videos where I had the neural network
learned to find high-level features
using PCA so that you have control over
what you generate using sliders whether
that be for images or music but I've
never tried to do that with text and
I've always wanted what those principal
components would change in a sentence
the other thing I wanted to do was try
out some new state-of-the-art techniques
if you haven't heard of GPT - it's open
a is amazing new text generator that
creates sentences at basically a human
level I'll put a link in the description
where you can try it out it's really
neat one of the things they did was to
use a creative solution to the encoding
problem you see there's typically two
obvious ways to encode text for a neural
network either at the character level or
at the word level at the character level
the network generates text one character
at a time it only has to choose between
maybe 100 to 200 different letters and
symbols which keeps its small and memory
efficient but it's very difficult to
build up sentence context from so many
steps in the past to make good
predictions in the future with a word
level encoding the network generates one
word at a time that makes the past
high-level context much closer and
easier to predict from and it generally
outperforms character level encoding but
there's a lot of possible words it needs
to choose from dictionaries are
typically 20,000 50 thousand or a
hundred thousand words which creates
enormous slow inefficient networks
because the vast majority of words are
rarely used plus there's a ton of
redundancy with similar words or typos
and unlike character level encoding it's
impossible to feed in or output new
words that aren't in the dictionary so
obviously we want something that gets us
the best of both and they achieve this
using something called bite pair
encoding basically you start out at the
character level but you run some
statistics over your entire data set to
find what pairs of letters are most
common together then you merge those
pairs to create a single token and add
it to your dictionary this keeps
repeating recursively until the
dictionary reaches some reasonable size
the tokens can also combine with letters
or other tokens to create even larger
ones in the end the dictionary is
entirely things like frequent pairs
prefixes suffixes or common words so
it's very efficient with minimum
redundancy like the character encoding
while still keeping high level context
like the word encoding and it does seem
to work better another thing they did
was to use an attention model but one
thing at a time I think I'll try that in
a future project so anyway this was the
model I ended up with it's similar to
the youtube comment generator but I'm
using an embedding encoder for the
context instead of a video title if you
want a good explanation about what an
embedding encoder is it's explained
really well in my garfield video I
decided to use a dictionary of 800
tokens for no particular reason but it
felt like a good balance all right
here's the exciting part
what is that top principle component
what traits affect the class names the
most well let's check it out in one
direction it seems to be classes about
arts crafts and creativity in the
opposite direction we get classes about
business productivity and management
that's a really amazing split that the
unsupervised AI was able to learn on its
own it's a very human way to do it Gil
share is pretty evenly split between
those categories so it does make a lot
of sense the next component is really
surprising it took me a little while to
figure out but it seems to reliably
control if the course is about software
and technology or not that's also a
pretty good split and you can see how
that's orthogonal to our first component
since each combination exists
independently number three seems to
control how the title starts either a
how-to or learn how to style or on the
other side something else the fourth
component well at this point I couldn't
really seem to find the pattern anymore
and likewise for the rest of them I kind
of expected that though because if you
look at the eigenvalues which are the
strength of each component you can see
that passed around four they all have
very similar values so it becomes really
hard to separate any features but
despite that you still get some really
funny classes and I would love to see
somebody try to teach these as usual you
can download the app and source code
from the description if you want to try
it out yourself I also want to mention
that PCA wasn't strictly necessary
because Skillshare already categorizes
the classes into 34 different categories
the results were much better within each
category but since each original class
only had one category mixing them
doesn't really work well and as fun as
it would be to make an awesome demon
network with this abstract Facebook and
health you should probably check out
their real classes on Skillshare if you
want to actually learn something useful
and if you're interested in machine
learning projects like this one without
getting so technical I can recommend the
course demystifying artificial
intelligence understanding machine
learning which is a great introduction
and right now all of my subscribers can
get Skillshare completely free for two
months if you use the link in the
description after that it's only ten
dollars a month for unlimited classes so
thanks again to Skillshare for allowing
me to use their data set and thanks to
all of you for watching
